title: U.S. SEC set to propose new rules limiting the powers of proxy advisers
text:
The rules would require proxy advising firms to give companies two chances to review voting recommendations before they are sent to shareholders. They would also increase the approval threshold for the level of shareholder support needed to force change at a company. The rules will be subject to a month-long period of public comment before a final vote. (Financial Times)

Talking point: This is the Securities and Exchange Commission’s second major move this year to rein in the power of proxy advisers. In August, it published a report clarifying that the firms are subject to anti-fraud legislation on materially false or misleading statements. Proxy-advising firms give shareholders advice on how to vote on various corporate issues from gender equity to executive compensation. Asset managers, overloaded with information from having to consider a high number of votes, commonly outsource this part of their jobs, and a study of 175 asset managers suggests they abide by the recommendations of their proxy advisers 95 per cent of the time. In the U.S., 97 per cent of the proxy-advising industry is dominated by two major firms: Institutional Shareholder Services and Glass Lewis. Critics say they have outsized power in capital markets to the point where they now serve as quasi-regulators operating without statutory oversight.
